Your full name: JAMES ROBERT CRAWFORD
Present Address: Saskatoon, Sask.
Pioneer Address: Edgell School Dist.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1902

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the QUESTIONNAIRE.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? We didn't mind driving 6 or 7 miles these days. How many of these were bachelor's homes? Around 6 or 7.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a year perhaps.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Week days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Just when we took an interest. Everybody was welcome in those days.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Generally in the Afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? You would be very disappointed if you didn't stay for our meal.

Was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Everybody was glad to see anybody. The house was always filled back up.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? They would count an insult if you didn't stay for at least one meal.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "block after the places"? Yes, but families were quite small in those days.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Sometimes.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Quilting bees as quilts were not any too plentiful in those times.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Yes, dances. I remember a surprise party came to our house in 1907 and there came up a blizzard so everybody stood until daylight next morning. Of course a suitable tally always brought lunch with them, the host provided tea & coffee every body welcomed. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. No

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times; - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No only private meetings between close neighbors.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Boy socials & Community dances, etc., whist drives

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? Where dances were held in the school

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist

Was there card playing for a prize? Sometimes

What dances were popular? Square usually

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. An odd one objected to dancing at first but later joined in

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Same as above but later joined in

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. July 1st 1917

26. Who organized it? The Gain Brothers

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? Yes

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? I think it was about the first.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Ball games & races

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? We spread table cloths on the grass & we all got around & everybody just helped themselves.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Tea & Coffee

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 1 O'clock in the afternoon & until 7 O'clock in the evening
